ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided a helpful survey of a bunch of topics using Python. Also, the bash scripting and UNIX units helped me better understand how to run jobs on the computing cluster.
Learned how to code in Python proficiently, learned about data structures (queues, stacks, heaps, trees), learned about cryptography, and learned how to utilize object-oriented programming.
I learned how to code in python and learned about the more intricate details about how the language works.
Python basics, data structures, object-oriented programming, some Unix, a bit of SQL, and a bit of cryptography
I learned a variety of python-related skills and concepts.
I learned how to code in Python

Learn briefly about cryptography, all things Python, a bit of SQL. Take this course for a really great overview of several interesting programming topics, and to become fluent in Python (a really great language).
Great introduction to the basics of python.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It makes absolutely zero sense in any world to have handwritten midterms for a CS course. I can't imagine this is easier to grade either, so why were both of the midterms pencil-and-paper?? That's not useful in any scenario outside of the classroom and unnecessarily stressful for students. Also I felt that the lectures did not necessarily translate to what was on the psets
I appreciate that the course covers a broad range of CS topics -- I found it informative as a non-major. Also a good intro to Python.

The course was taught well and in depth 
.People seemed disengaged with the course. I did not like the no collaboration policy, because I feel like in the actual CS world collaboration is a key component of program development.
Strengths: Broad range of topics, caring professor, kind TAs.
Much of the class feels self-taught or heavily aided by the TAs.
The psets are super helpful & reflect the lectures.

Strengths: PSETS are really well designed, TA's are incredibly helpful and you really come out learning a lot about Python. Slade knows a lot about the language. This was a pretty small class, it almost felt like a seminar. Weaknesses: Slade is a bit of a quiet lecturer, so don't expect a ton of engagement with the course. However, if you have questions he will always be able to answer it.
The content was great, though the lecturing style was not the most engaging as it was mostly the professor talking at the students the whole time rather than encouraging participation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If it's required, it's not horrid. But wouldn't take for fun
Sure! It's a chill intro course where you'll still learn a good amount.
Anyone who wants a somewhat scattered introduction to Python may benefit from this course.
Yes; great way to get a solid introduction to essential programming skills for anyone who isn't a comp sci major.
Yes if you want to learn python well.
I would recommend this courseI learned a lot and felt supported throughout the process.
If you have to take this course for either the certificate or CS major(s), I think I would recommend this course over CPSC 201. But other than that, it does not serve as a good exploratory course.
This is one of the best CS courses offered at Yale. It covers the basics of CS internship questions.

Yes. Take this course to learn Python. I didn't know any python going in, but coming out it is another tool in my arsenal as a CS major. Also, I believe this course is required if you want the programming certificate.
Yes, for anyone looking to develop basic programming skills in the very useful language of python!
